\- Manufacture of machines used in book binding, under class 2829 (Manufacture of other special-purpose machinery);

**2829: Manufacture of other special-purpose machinery**

This class includes the manufacture of special-purpose machines not elsewhere classified.

**28291: Manufacture of machinery for producing building materials**

This class includes the manufacture of machinery for producing roof tiles, wall tiles, floor tiles, ceramic pastes, mixed substances, conduit, graphite electrodes, board chalk, foundry moulds, etc.

**28299: Manufacture of other special-purpose machinery not elsewhere classified**

This class includes:

\- Manufacture of machinery for making paper pulp;

\- Manufacture of machinery for making paper and paperboard;

\- Manufacture of dryers for wood, paper pulp, paper or paperboard;

\- Manufacture of machinery producing articles of paper or paperboard;

\- Manufacture of machinery for working soft rubber or plastics or for production of materials: Extruders, moulders, pneumatic tyre making or retreading machines and other machines for making a specific rubber or plastic product;

\- Manufacture of printing and book-binding machines and machinery for activities that support printing on textile and other materials;

\- Manufacture of machinery for producing semi-conductors;

\- Manufacture of industrial robots for various uses;

\- Manufacture of diverse machinery and equipment for:

\+ Production of electric lamps, tubes (valves) or bulbs,

\+ Production of hot-worked glass or glassware, glass fiber or yarn,

\+ Machinery for isotopic separation.

\- Manufacture of tire alignment and balancing equipment; balancing equipment;

\- Manufacture of central greasing systems;

\- Manufacture of aircraft landing equipment, aircraft carrier catapults and related equipment;

\- Manufacture of tanning beds;

\- Manufacture of automatic ball serving equipment (e.g. pin-setters);

\- Manufacture of equipment for shooting galleries, swimming and other amusements.

**Exclusion:**

\- Manufacture of household-type appliances, under class 27500 (Manufacture of consumer electronics);

\- Manufacture of photocopy machines, etc., under class 28170 (Manufacture of office machinery and equipment, except computers and peripheral equipment);

\- Manufacture of machinery and equipment to work hard rubber, hard plastics and cold glass, under class 28220 (Manufacture of machine tools and metal-form machinery);

\- Manufacture of ingot moulds, under class 28230 (Manufacture of machinery for metallurgy);

**29: MANUFACTURE OF MOTOR VEHICLES**

This division includes the manufacture of motor vehicles for transporting passengers and freight, as well as the manufacture of various parts and accessories, and of trailers and semi-trailers;

Maintenance and repair of vehicles produced in this division are classified under 45200 (Maintenance and repair of motor vehicles).

**291 - 2910 - 29100: Manufacture of motor vehicles**

This class includes:

\- Manufacture of passenger cars;

\- Manufacture of commercial vehicles: Vans, over-the-road tractors for semi-trailers, etc.

\- Manufacture of buses, trolleybus and coaches;

 - Manufacture of motor vehicle engines;

\- Manufacture of chassis fitted with engines;

\- Manufacture of motor vehicle engines;

\+ Manufacture of snowmobiles, golf carts, amphibious airplanes,

\+ Fire engines, street sweepers, travelling libraries, armored cars, etc.

\+ Concrete-mixer lorries,

\+ ATVs, go-carts and similar vehicles including race cars.

This class also includes the activities of factory rebuilding of motor vehicles.

**Exclusion:**

\- Manufacture of lighting equipment for motor vehicles and non-motorized vehicles, under class 27400 (Manufacture of electric lighting equipment);

\- Manufacture of pistons, piston rings and carburetors, under class 28110 (Manufacture of engines and turbines, except aircraft, automobile and motorcycle engines);

\- Manufacture of agricultural tractors, under class 28210 (Manufacture of agricultural and forestry machinery);

\- Manufacture of tractors used in construction and mining, under class 28240 (Manufacture of machinery for mining, quarrying and construction);

\- Manufacture of dumping trucks, under class 28240 (Manufacture of machinery for mining, quarrying and construction);

\- Manufacture of bodies for motor vehicles, under class 29200 (Manufacture of bodies for motor vehicles, of trailers and semi-trailers);

\- Manufacture of electrical parts for motor vehicles, under class 29300 (Manufacture of parts and accessories for motor vehicles and automotive engines);

\- Manufacture of parts and accessories for motor vehicles, under class 42200 (Construction of utility projects);

\- Manufacture of tanks and military vehicles, under class 30400 (Manufacture of military fighting vehicles).

\- Maintenance, repair and minor alteration of motor vehicles, under class 45200 (Maintenance and repair of motor vehicles).

**292 - 2920 - 29200: Manufacture of bodies for motor vehicles, of trailers and semi-trailers**

This class includes:

\- Manufacture of bodies, including cabs for motor vehicles;

\- Outfitting of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers;

\- Manufacture of trailers and semi-trailers: For transport of goods: oil tankers; for transport of passengers: caravan trailers;

\- Manufacture of containers for carriage by one or more modes of transport.

**Exclusion:**

\- Manufacture of trailers and semi-trailers specially designed for use in agriculture, under class 28210 (Manufacture of agricultural and forestry machinery);

\- Manufacture of parts and accessories of bodies for motor vehicles, under class 29300 (Manufacture of parts and accessories for motor vehicles and automotive engines);

\- Manufacture of non-motorized vehicles drawn by animals, under class 30990 (Manufacture of other transport equipment not elsewhere classified);

**293 - 2930 - 29300: Manufacture of parts and accessories for motor vehicles and automotive engines**

This class includes:

\- Manufacture of replacement parts and components for motor vehicles: Brakes, gearboxes, axles, road wheels, shock absorbers, radiators, silencers, exhaust pipes, catalytic converters, clutches, steering wheels, steering columns and steering boxes;

\- Manufacture of parts and accessories of bodies for motor vehicles: Safety belts, airbags, windows, bumpers;

\- Manufacture of car seats;

\- Manufacture of electrical equipment for motor vehicles, such as generators, alternators, spark plugs, ignition wiring harnesses, electric-powered window and door systems, assembly of gauges into engines, voltage regulators, etc.

**Exclusion:**

\- Manufacture of tyres, under class 22110 (Manufacture of rubber tyres and tubes; retreading and rebuilding of rubber tyres);

\- Manufacture of rubber hoses and belts and other rubber products, under class 22120 (Manufacture of other rubber products);

**30: MANUFACTURE OF OTHER TRANSPORT EQUIPMENT**

This division includes the manufacture of transportation equipment such as shipbuilding and boat manufacturing; manufacture of locomotives and railroad rolling stock, aircrafts, spacecrafts and parts thereof.

**301: Building of ships and boats**

This group includes the activities of building of ships, boats and other floating structures for transportation and other commercial purposes, as well as for sports and recreational purposes.

**3011 - 30110: Building of ships and floating structures**

This class includes the activities of building of ships, except vessels for sports or recreation, and construction of floating structures.

This class includes:

\- Building of commercial vessels: passenger ships, ferry boats, cargo ships, tankers, tugs, etc.

\- Building of warships;

\- Building of fishing boats and fish-processing factory vessels. This class also includes:

\- Building of hovercraft (except recreation-type hovercraft);

\- Construction of drilling platforms, floating or submersible vessels;

\- Construction of floating structures: Floating docks, pontoons, coffer-dams, floating landing stages, buoys, floating tanks, barges, floating cranes, non-recreational inflatable rafts, etc.

\- Manufacture of sections for ships and floating structures.

**Exclusion:**

\- Manufacture of parts of vessels, which are not major hull assemblies:

\+ Manufacture of sails, under class 13220 (Manufacture of made-up textile articles, except wearing apparel);

\+ Production of ships’ propellers, under class 2599 (Manufacture of other fabricated metal products not elsewhere classified);

\+ Production of steel or iron anchors, under class 2599 (Manufacture of other fabricated metal products not elsewhere classified);

Manufacture of marine vessels’ engines, under class 28110 (Manufacture of engines and turbines, except aircraft, automobile and motorcycle engines);

\- Manufacture of naval instruments, under class 26510 (Manufacture of measuring, testing, navigating and control equipment);

\- Manufacture of lighting equipment for ships, under class 27400 (Manufacture of electric lighting equipment);

\- Manufacture of engines for amphibious airplanes, under class 29100 (Manufacture of motor vehicles);

\- Manufacture of inflatable rafts and rafts for recreation, under class 30120 (Building of pleasure and sporting boats);

\- Specialized repair and maintenance of ships and floating structures, under class 33150 (Repair and maintenance of transport equipment, except motor vehicles);

\- Ship breaking, under class 3830 (Materials recovery);

\- Interior installation of boats, under class 43300 (Building completion and finishing).

**3012 - 30120: Building of pleasure and sporting boats**

This class includes:

\- Manufacture of inflatable boats and rafts;

\- Building of sailboats with or without auxiliary motor;

\- Building of motor boats;

\- Building of recreation-type hovercraft;

\- Building of personal amphibious airplanes;

\- Building of other tourist and sporting boats: Canoes, kayaks (lightweight wood boats), rowing boats, skiffs.

**Exclusion:**

\- Manufacture of parts of tourist and sporting boats:

\+ Manufacture of sails, under class 13220 (Manufacture of made-up textile articles, except wearing apparel);

\+ Production of iron or steel anchors, under class 2599 (Manufacture of other fabricated metal products not elsewhere classified);

Manufacture of marine vessels’ engines, under class 28110 (Manufacture of engines and turbines, except aircraft, automobile and motorcycle engines);

\- Manufacture of sailboards and surfboards, under class 32300 (Manufacture of sports goods);

\- Maintenance, repair or alteration of tourist boats, under class 33150 (Repair and maintenance of transport equipment, except motor vehicles);

**302 - 3020 - 30200: Manufacture of railway locomotives, trams and rail cars**

This class includes:

\- Manufacture of rail locomotives powered by electricity, diesel, steam, and other rail locomotives;

This class also includes:

\- Manufacture of mechanical and electronic signaling, safety and traffic control equipment for railways, tramways, inland waterways, roads, parking facilities, airfields, etc.

\- Manufacture of mining locomotives and mining rail cars;

\- Manufacture of railway car seats.

**Exclusion:**

\- Manufacture of unassembled rails, under class 24100 (Manufacture of iron, steel, cast iron);

\- Production of railway track fixtures, under class 2599 (Manufacture of other fabricated metal products not elsewhere classified);

\- Manufacture of electric motors, under class 2710 (Manufacture of electric motors, generators, transformers and electricity distribution and control apparatus);

\- Manufacture of electronic signaling, safety or traffic-control equipment, under class 27900 (Manufacture of other electrical equipment);

\- Manufacture of engines and turbines, under class 28110 (Manufacture of engines and turbines, except aircraft, automobile and motorcycle engines);

**Exclusion:**

**309: Manufacture of other transport equipment not elsewhere classified**

**31: MANUFACTURE OF FURNITURE**

This division includes:

Manufacture of furniture and related products of any material except stone, concrete and ceramics. The processes used in the manufacture of furniture are standard methods of forming materials and assembling components, including cutting, moulding and laminating. The design of the articles, for both aesthetic and functional qualities, is an important aspect of the production process.

Some of the processes used in furniture production are similar to processes that are used in other segments of manufacturing. For example, the process of cutting and assembly in the production of wood are classified in division 16 (Manufacture of wood and wood products). However, the multiple processes distinguish the production of wood furniture from the manufacture of wood products. Similarly, the manufacture of metal furniture uses techniques that are also employed in the production of roll-formed products classified in division 25 (Manufacture of fabricated metal products, except machinery and equipment). The moulding process for plastic furniture is similar to the moulding of other plastics products. However, the manufacture of plastic furniture tends to be a specialized activity.

**310 - 3100: Manufacture of furniture**

This class includes the manufacture of wood articles for various uses in all places.

This class includes:

**32: OTHER MANUFACTURING**

This division includes the manufacture of a variety of goods not covered in other parts of the classification. Since this is a residual division, production processes, input materials and use of the produced goods can vary widely and usual criteria for grouping classes into divisions have not been applied here.

**321: Manufacture of jewellery, imitation jewellery and related articles**

This group includes the manufacture of jewellery and imitation jewellery articles.

This class also includes the manufacture of personal engraved product of precious and non-precious metal.

**Exclusion:**

**33: REPAIR, MAINTENANCE AND INSTALLATION OF MACHINERY AND EQUIPMENT**

This division includes:

\- Repair and maintenance of industrial machinery and equipment with the aim to restore machinery, equipment and other products to working order. The provision of general or routine maintenance on such products is to ensure they work efficiently and to prevent breakdown and unnecessary repairs.

\- This division includes specialized repair and maintenance activities. A substantial amount of repair is also done by manufacturers of machinery, equipment and other goods, in which case the classification of units engaged in these repair and manufacturing activities is done according to the value-added principle which would often assign these combined activities to the manufacture of the good. The same principle is applied for combined trade and repair;

\- The rebuilding or remanufacturing of machinery and equipment is considered a manufacturing activity;

\- Repair and maintenance of goods that are utilized as capital goods as well as consumer goods are typically classified as repair and maintenance of household goods (e.g. office and household furniture repair, see class 95240 (Repair of furniture and home furnishings).

This division also includes the specialized installation of machinery. However, the installation of equipment that forms an integral part of buildings or similar structures, such as installation of wiring or air-conditioning systems, is classified as construction.

**Exclusion:**

\- Cleaning of industrial machinery, under class 81290 (Other building and industrial cleaning activities);

\- Repair and maintenance of computers and communications equipment, under group 951 (Repair of computers and communication equipment);

\- Repair and maintenance of household goods, under group 952 (Repair of personal and household goods).

**331: Repair and maintenance of machinery, equipment and fabricated metal products**

This group includes the repair and maintenance of fabricated metal products, machinery and equipment, including specialized repair of goods produced in the manufacturing sector, with the aim to restore metal products, machinery, equipment and other products to working order.

This group also includes the provision of general or routine maintenance on such products is to ensure they work efficiently and to prevent breakdown and unnecessary repairs.

**Exclusion:**

\- Rebuilding or remanufacturing of machinery and equipment, under corresponding classes in divisions 25 to 31;

\- Cleaning of industrial machinery, under class 81290 (Other building and industrial cleaning activities);

\- Repair and maintenance of computers and communications equipment, under group 951 (Repair of computers and communication equipment);

\- Repair of photocopy machines.

**Exclusion:**

Installation of industrial furnaces and other heating equipment, under class 4322 (Plumbing, heat and air-conditioning installation).

**3313 - 33130: Repair of electronic and optical equipment**

This class includes:

\- Repair and maintenance of equipment produced in group 265 (Manufacture of measuring, testing, navigating and control equipment; manufacture of watches and clocks), in group 266 (Manufacture of irradiation, electromedical and electrotherapeutic equipment) and in group 267 (Manufacture of optical instruments and equipment), except those that are considered household goods.

\- Repair and maintenance of the measuring, testing, navigating and control equipment of group 265 (Manufacture of measuring, testing, navigating and control equipment; manufacture of watches and clocks), such as:

\+ Aircraft engine instruments;

\+ Automotive emissions testing equipment;

\+ Meteorological instruments;

\+ Chemical, physical and electrical properties testing and supervision equipment;

\+ Surveying instruments;

\+ Radiation detection and monitoring equipment.

This class also includes:

\- Repair and maintenance of X-ray, electromedical and electrotherapeutic equipment of class 2660 (Manufacture of irradiation, electromedical and electrotherapeutic equipment), such as:

\+ Magnetic resonance imaging equipment,     

\+ Medical ultrasound equipment,

\+ Pacemakers,

\+ Hearing aids,

\+ Electrocardiographs,

\+ Endoscopic equipment,

\+ Medical imaging devices.

\- Repair of optical instruments and equipment of class 2670 (Manufacture of optical instruments and equipment), such as magnifying glass, binoculars, microscopes (except electron and proton microscopes), telescopes, prisms and lenses (except ophthalmic ones), photographic equipment, if the use of such equipment is mainly commercial.

**Exclusion:**

\- Repair of photocopy machines, under class 33120 (Repair of machinery and equipment);

\- Repair and maintenance of computers and peripheral equipment, under class 95110 (Repair of computers and peripheral equipment);

\- Repair of computer projectors, under class 95110 (Repair of computers and peripheral equipment);

\- Repair and maintenance of communication equipment, under class 95120 (Repair of communication equipment);

\- Repair of commercial televisions and video cameras, under class 95120 (Repair of communication equipment);

\- Repair of household-type video cameras, under class 95210 (Repair of audiovisual consumer electronics);

\- Repair of watches and clocks, under class 95290 (Repair of other personal and household goods).

**3314 - 33140: Repair of electrical equipment**

This class includes:

Repair and maintenance of goods of division 27, except those in class 2750 (household appliances);

This class includes:

\- Repair and maintenance of power, distribution, and specialty transformers.

\- Repair and maintenance of electric motors, generators, and motor generator sets,

\- Repair and maintenance of switchboard and switchgear apparatus,

\- Repair and maintenance of relays and industrial controls,

\- Repair and maintenance of primary and storage batteries,

\- Repair and maintenance of electric lighting equipment,

\- Repair and maintenance of current-carrying and non current-carrying wiring devices for electrical circuits.

**Exclusion:**

\- Repair and maintenance of computers and peripheral equipment, under class 95110 (Repair of computers and peripheral equipment);

\- Repair and maintenance of telecommunications equipment, under class 95120 (Repair of communication equipment);

\- Repair and maintenance of consumer electronics, under class 95210 (Repair of audiovisual consumer electronics);

\- Repair of watches and clocks, under class 95290 (Repair of other personal and household goods).

**3315 - 33150: Repair and maintenance of transport equipment (except motor vehicles)**

This class includes:

\- Repair and maintenance of transport equipment of division 30 (Manufacture of other transport equipment), except motorcycles and bicycles. However, the factory rebuilding or overhaul of ships, locomotives, cars and aircraft is classified in division 30 (Manufacture of other transport equipment);

\- Repair and routine maintenance of ships;

\- Repair and maintenance of pleasure boats;

\- Repair of locomotives and rail cars (except rebuilding or conversion).

\- Aircraft repair and maintenance services (except conversion, overhaul and rebuilding);

\- Repair and maintenance of aircraft engines;

\- Repair of horse-drawn carriages and animal-drawn wagons.

**Exclusion:**

\- Factory rebuilding of ships, under group 301 (Building of ships and boats);

\- Rebuilding of locomotives and rolling stock, under class 30200 (Manufacture of railway locomotives, trams and rail cars);

\- Factory repair of aircraft, under class 30300 (Manufacture of aircraft, space craft and related machinery);

\- Ship scaling and dismantling, under class 3830 (Materials recovery);

\- Repair and maintenance of motorcycles, under group 454 (Sale, maintenance and repair of motorcycles and related parts and accessories);

\- Repair of bicycles, under class 95290 (Repair of other personal and household goods).

**3319 - 33190: Repair of other equipment**

This class includes the repair and maintenance of equipment not covered in other classes of this group.

This class includes:

\- Repair and mending of fishing nets;

\- Repair of ropes, riggings, sails, tarps;

\- Repair of bags storing fertilizers and chemicals;

\- Repair or reconditioning of wooden pallets, shipping drums or barrels, and similar items;

\- Repair of pinball machines and other coin-operated games, bowling equipment and similar items;

\- Restoring of organs and similar musical instruments.

**Exclusion:**

\- Repair of household-type and office-type furniture, and furniture restoration, under class 95240 (Repair of furniture and home furnishings);

\- Repair of bicycles, under class 95290 (Repair of other personal and household goods).

\- Repair of wearing apparel, under class 95290 (Repair of other personal and household goods).

**332 - 3320 - 33200: Installation of industrial machinery and equipment**

This class includes the specialized installation of machinery. However, the installation of equipment that forms an integral part of buildings or similar structures, such as installation of electrical wiring, burglar alarm systems or air-conditioning systems or elevators, is classified as construction.

This class includes:

\- Installation of industrial machinery in industrial factories;

\- Installation of industrial process control equipment;

\- Dismantling of large-scale machinery and equipment;

\- Activities of millwrights;

\- Machine rigging;

\- Installation of bowling alley equipment.

**D: MANUFACTURE AND DISTRIBUTION OF ELECTRICITY, GAS, HOT WATER, STEAM AND AIR CONDITIONING**

This section includes:

\- Activities of providing electric power, natural gas, steam, hot water through a permanent system (network) of mains and lines. The dimension of the network is not decisive. The distribution of electricity, gas, steam, hot water and the like in industrial parks or high-rise residential buildings is also included here;

\- Provision of electricity and gas, including the collection, supervision and distribution thereof. Supply of steam and air conditioning is also included.

**Exclusion:**

\- Provision of water and steam under division 36 (Water collection, treatment and supply) and division 37 (Sewerage);

\- Transport of gas through pipelines (typically in long distance).

**35: MANUFACTURE AND DISTRIBUTION OF ELECTRICITY, GAS, HOT WATER, STEAM AND AIR CONDITIONING**

**351 - 3510: Generation, transmission and distribution of electric power**

**35101: Manufacture of electric power**

This class includes the operation of generation facilities that produce bulk electric energy, e.g. thermal power, nuclear power, hydropower, gas turbine, diesel.

**Exclusion:** Production of electricity through incineration of waste, under class 38210 (Treatment and disposal of non-hazardous waste)

**35102: Transmission and distribution of electric power**

This class includes:

Transmission of electricity to distribution systems that distribute electric power to end users;

This class includes:

\- Activities of transmission systems that convey electricity from the generation facility to the distribution system;

\- Activities of distribution systems (i.e. a system consisting of lines, poles, meters and wiring), which convey electric power from the generation facility or the transmission system to the final consumer;

\- Sale of electricity to users;

\- Activities of electric power brokers or agents that arrange the sale of electricity via power distribution systems operated by other entities;

\- Activities of electricity and transmission capacity exchanges.

**352 - 3520 - 35200: Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains**

This class includes:

\- Manufacture of gas and distribution of natural or synthetic gas to the consumer through a system of mains. Gas vendors or brokers, who arrange the sale of natural gas over distribution systems operated by others, are included. The separate operation of gas supply, typically done over long distances and connecting producers with distributors of gas, or between urban centers, is classified with pipeline transport activities.

\- Production of gas for the purpose of gas supply from coal, from by-products of agriculture or from waste;

\- Manufacture of gaseous fuels with a specified calorific value, by purification, blending and other manufacturing processes from gases of various types including natural gas.

\- Transportation, distribution and supply of gaseous fuels of all kinds through a system of mains;

\- Sale of gas to the user through mains;

\- Activities of gas brokers and agents that arrange the sale of gas over gas distribution systems operated by others;

\- Sale or exchange of gaseous fuels and transport capacity.

**Exclusion:**

\- Operation of coke ovens, under class 19100 (Manufacture of coke oven products);

\- Production of refined petroleum products, under class 19200 (Manufacture of refined petroleum products);

\- Manufacture of industrial gases under class 20110 (Manufacture of basic chemicals);

\- Wholesale of gaseous fuels, under class 4661 (Wholesale of solid, liquid and gaseous fuels and related products);

\- Retail sale of bottled gas, under class 4773 (Other retail sale of new goods in specialized stores);

\- Direct selling of fuel, under class 47990 (Other retail sale not elsewhere classified);

\- Transportation of gases (over long distance) by pipelines, under class 49400 (Transport via pipeline).

**353 - 3530: Manufacture and supply of steam, hot water, air conditioning and ice**

**35301: Manufacture and supply of steam, hot water and air conditioning**

This class includes:

\- Production, collection and distribution of steam and hot water for heating, power and other purposes;

\- Production and distribution of cooled air;

\- Manufacture and distribution of chilled water for cooling purposes.

**Exclusion:** Production of ice for food or non-food (e.g. cooling) purposes, under class 35302 (Manufacture of ice);

**35302: Manufacture of ice**

This class includes the production of ice for food or cooling purposes.

**E: WATER SUPPLY; MANAGEMENT AND REMEDIATION OF WASTE AND WASTEWATER**

This section includes the activities related to the management (including collection, treatment and disposal) of various forms of waste, such as solid or non-solid industrial or household waste, as well as contaminated sites. The output of the waste or sewage treatment process can either be disposed of or become an input into other production processes. Activities of water supply are also grouped in this section, since they are often carried out in connection with or by units also engaged in the treatment of sewage.

**36: WATER COLLECTION, TREATMENT AND SUPPLY**

This division includes the collection, treatment and distribution of water for industrial and household needs.

This division also includes the collection of water from various sources, and distribution thereof by various means.

**360 - 3600 - 36000: Water collection, treatment and supply**

This class includes the collection, treatment and distribution of water for industrial and household needs. Collection of water from various sources, and distribution thereof by various means are also included in this class.

The operation of irrigation canals is also included; however, the provision of irrigation services through sprinklers and similar agricultural support services are not included here.

This class includes:

\- Collection of water from rivers, lakes, ponds, etc.

\- Collection of rain water,

\- Purification of water for purposes of water supply,

\- Treatment of water for industrial and other uses,

\- Desalting of seawater to produce water as the principal product of interest,

\- Distribution of water through mains, by trucks or by other means,

\- Operation of irrigation canals.

**Exclusion:**

\- Operation of irrigation systems and equipment for agricultural purposes, under class 01610 (Cultivation service activities),

\- Treatment of wastewater in order to prevent pollution, under class 3700 (Sewerage);

\- Transportation of water (over long distance) via pipelines, under class 49400 (Transport via pipeline).

**37: SEWERAGE**

This division includes the operation of sewer systems or sewage treatment facilities that collect, treat and dispose of sewage.

**370 - 3700: Sewerage**

**37001: Discharge**

This class includes:

\- Operation of sewer systems for drainage of wastewater,

\- Collection and Transportation of industrial or human wastewater from one or several users, as well as rain water by means of sewerage networks, collectors, tanks and other means of transport (sewage vehicles, etc.)

\- Maintenance and cleaning of sewers and drains.

**37002: Treatment**

This class includes:

\- Operation of sewage treatment facilities;

\- Treatment of wastewater (including human and industrial wastewater, water from swimming pools, etc.) by means of physical, chemical and biological processes like dilution, screening, filtering, sedimentation, etc.

\- Emptying and cleaning of cesspools and septic tanks with sanitary chemicals.

**38: WASTE COLLECTION, TREATMENT AND DISPOSAL; MATERIALS RECOVERY**

This division includes the collection, treatment and disposal of waste. This also includes hauling of waste materials and the operation of materials recovery facilities (i.e. those that sort recoverable materials from a waste stream).

**381: Waste collection**

This group includes the collection of waste from households and businesses by means of refuse bins, wheeled bins, containers, etc. It includes collection of non-hazardous and hazardous waste, e.g. waste from households, used batteries, used cooking oils and fats, waste oil from ships and used oil from garages, as well as construction and demolition waste.

**3811 - 38110: Collection of non-hazardous waste**

This class includes:

\- Collection of non-hazardous solid waste (i.e. kitchen garbage) within a local area, such as collection of waste, possibly including mixed recoverable materials, from households and businesses by means of refuse bins, wheeled bins, containers, etc.;

\- Collection of recyclable materials;

\- Collection of used cooking oils and fats;

\- Collection of refuse in litter-bins in public places;

\- Collection of construction and demolition waste;

\- Collection and removal of debris such as tree branch and rubble;

\- Collection of waste output of textile mills;

\- Operation of stations collecting non-hazardous waste.

**Exclusion:**

\- Collection of hazardous waste, under class 3812 (Collection of hazardous waste);

\- Operation of landfills for the disposal of non-hazardous waste, under class 3821 (Treatment and disposal of non-hazardous waste);

\- Operation of facilities where commingled recoverable materials such as paper, plastics, etc. are sorted into distinct categories, under class 3830 (Materials recovery).

**3812: Collection of hazardous waste**

This class includes the collection of solid and non-solid hazardous waste, i.e. explosive, oxidizing, flammable, toxic, irritant, carcinogenic, corrosive, infectious and other substances and preparations harmful for human health and environment. It may also entail identification, treatment, packaging and labeling of waste for the purposes of transport.

**38121: Collection of medical waste**

This class includes the collection of waste from medical facilities.

**38129: Collection of other hazardous waste**

This class includes:

\- Collection of solid and non-solid hazardous waste, i.e. explosive, oxidizing, flammable, toxic, irritant, carcinogenic, corrosive, infectious and other substances and preparations harmful for human health and environment;

\- Collection of used oil from ships or garages;

\- Collection of bio-hazardous waste;

\- Used batteries;

\- Operation of waste transfer stations for hazardous waste.

**Exclusion:** Remediation and clean-up of contaminated buildings, mine sites, soil, ground water, e.g. asbestos removal, under class 39000 (Remediation and other waste management activities).

**382: Waste treatment and disposal**

This group includes the activities of treatment prior to disposal of various forms of waste by different means, such as treatment of organic waste with the aim of disposal; treatment and disposal of toxic live or dead animals and other contaminated waste; treatment and disposal of transition radioactive waste from hospitals; dumping of refuse on land or in water; burial or ploughing-under of refuse; disposal of used goods such as refrigerators to eliminate harmful waste; disposal of waste by combustion. The generation of electricity resulting from waste incineration process is also included.

**Exclusion:** Treatment and disposal of wastewater, under class 3700 (Sewerage);

**3821 - 38210: Treatment and disposal of non-hazardous waste**

This class includes:

Pre-disposal treatment and other treatment of solid and non-solid non-hazardous waste.

\+ Operation of landfills for the disposal of non-hazardous waste,

\+ Disposal of non-hazardous waste by combustion or incineration or other methods, with or without the resulting production of electricity or steam, substitute fuels, biogas, ashes or other by-products for further uses,

\+ Treatment of organic waste for disposal.

\+ Production of compost from organic waste.

**Exclusion:**

\- Combustion and incineration of hazardous waste, under class 38229 (Treatment and disposal of other hazardous waste);

\- Operation of facilities where commingled recoverable materials such as paper, plastics, used beverage cans and metals are sorted into distinct categories, under class 3830 (Materials recovery).

\- Decontamination and clean-up of land and water or toxic material abatement, under class 39000 (Remediation activities and other waste management services).

**3822: Treatment and disposal of hazardous waste**

This class includes the activities of treatment prior to disposal of solid and non-solid hazardous waste that includes explosive, oxidizing, flammable, toxic, irritant, carcinogenic, corrosive, infectious and other substances and preparations harmful for human health and environment.

**38221: Treatment and disposal of medical waste**

This class includes the activities of treatment and disposal of waste from medical facilities.

**38229: Treatment and disposal of other hazardous waste**

This class includes:

\- Operation of facilities for treatment of hazardous waste;

\- Treatment and disposal of contaminated live or dead animals and other pathogenic waste;

\- Incineration of hazardous waste;

\- Disposal of used goods such as refrigerators to eliminate harmful waste;

\- Treatment, disposal and storage of radioactive nuclear waste:

\+ Treatment and disposal of transition radioactive waste, i.e. agents decaying within the period of transport, from hospitals,

\+ Encapsulation, preparation and other treatment of nuclear waste for storage.

**Exclusion:**

\- Incineration of non-hazardous waste, under class 38210 (Treatment and disposal of other non-hazardous waste);

\- Decontamination and clean-up of land and water or toxic material abatement, under class 39000 (Remediation activities and other waste management services).

\- Reprocessing of nuclear fuels, under class 20110 (Manufacture of basic chemicals).

**383 - 3830: Materials recovery**

This class includes the activities of processing of metal and non-metal waste and scrap into new raw materials for various uses. Such process can involve a mechanical or chemical technique. Recovery of materials from waste streams in the form of separating and sorting recoverable materials from non-hazardous waste (i.e. kitchen garbage) or separating and sorting of commingled recoverable materials, such as paper, plastics, used beverage cans and metals, into distinct categories.

**38301: Recovery of metal waste**

This class includes:

\- Mechanical crushing of metal waste such as used cars, washing machines, bikes with subsequent separation and sorting;

\- Dismantling of automobiles, computers, televisions and other equipment for materials recovery;

\- Reduction of large iron pieces such as railway wagons;

\- Shredding of metal waste, such as end-of-life vehicles;

\- Other methods of mechanical treatment as cutting and pressing to reduce the volume;

\- Ship breaking.

**38302: Recovery of non-metal waste**

This class includes:

\- Reclaiming metals out of photographic waste, e.g. fixer solution or photographic films and paper;

\- Reclaiming of rubber such as used tires to produce new raw material;

\- Sorting and combination of plastics to produce new raw material for tubes, flower pots, pallets and similar articles;

\- Processing (cleaning, melting, grinding) of plastic or rubber waste to granulates;

\- Crushing, cleaning and sorting of glass;

\- Crushing, cleaning and sorting of other waste such as demolition waste to obtain raw materials;

\- Processing of used cooking oils and fats into raw materials;

\- Treatment of waste from food, beverage and tobacco and residual substances into new raw materials.

**Exclusion:**

\- Manufacture of new final products from (whether or not self-produced) secondary raw materials, such as making pulp from paper waste, retreading tyres or production of metal from metal scrap, under corresponding classes in section C (Manufacturing);

\- Reprocessing of nuclear fuels, under class 20110 (Manufacture of basic chemicals);

\- Treatment and disposal of non-hazardous waste, under class 38210 (Treatment and disposal of other non-hazardous waste);

\- Treatment of organic waste for disposal, under class 38210 (Treatment and disposal of other non-hazardous waste);

\- Energy recovery from non-hazardous waste incineration processes, under class 38210 (Treatment and disposal of other non-hazardous waste);

\- Disposal of used goods such as refrigerators to eliminate harmful waste, under class 3822 (Treatment and disposal of hazardous waste);

\- Treatment and disposal of transition radioactive waste from hospitals, under class 3822 (Treatment and disposal of hazardous waste);

\- Treatment and disposal of toxic or polluting waste, under class 3822 (Treatment and disposal of other hazardous waste);

\- Dismantling of automobiles, computers, televisions and other equipment to obtain and re-sell usable parts, under section G (Wholesale and retail trade; repair of motor vehicles and motorcycles);

\- Wholesale of recoverable materials, under class 4669 (Other specialized wholesale trade not elsewhere classified).

**39: REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES AND OTHER WASTE MANAGEMENT SERVICES**

This division includes the provision of remediation services, i.e. the cleanup of contaminated buildings and sites, soil, surface or ground water.

**390 - 3900 - 39000: Remediation activities and other waste management services**

This class includes:

\- Decontamination of soils and groundwater at the current or previous place of pollution, by mechanical, chemical or biological methods;

\- Decontamination of industrial factories or sites, including nuclear plants and sites;

\- Decontamination and clean-up of surface water contaminated accidentally, e.g. through collection of pollutants or through application of chemicals;

\- Cleanup of oil spills and other pollutions on land, in surface water, in ocean and seas, including coastal areas;

\- Abatement of asbestos, lead paint or other toxic materials;

\- Other specialized pollution-control activities.

**Exclusion:**

\- Treatment and disposal of non-hazardous waste, under class 38210 (Treatment and disposal of other non-hazardous waste);

\- Treatment and disposal of hazardous waste, under class 3822 (Treatment and disposal of other hazardous waste);

\- Outdoor sweeping and watering of streets, under class 81290 (Other building cleaning activities).

**F: CONSTRUCTION**

**41: CONSTRUCTION OF BUILDINGS**

The section includes all activities of general and specialized construction for buildings.

It includes new work, repair, expansion and renovation, erection of prefabricated structures on the site and construction of buildings of a temporary nature.

General construction is the construction of dwellings, office buildings, stores and other public and utility buildings, farm buildings etc., or the construction of civil engineering works such as motorways, streets, bridges, tunnels, railways, airfields, harbors and other water projects, irrigation systems, sewerage systems, industrial facilities, pipelines and electric lines, sports facilities, etc. This work can be carried out on one’s own account or on a fee or contract basis. Portions of the work and sometimes even the whole practical work can be subcontracted out. A unit that carries the overall responsibility for a construction project is classified here. Repair of residences and civil engineering works is also included.

The section includes the complete construction of buildings (division 41), the complete construction of civil engineering works (division 42), as well as specialized construction activities, if carried out only as a part of the construction process (division 43).

The renting of construction equipment with an operator is classified to the specific construction activity carried out with this equipment.

This section also includes the development of building projects for buildings or civil engineering works by bringing together financial, technical and physical means to realize the construction projects for later sale. If these activities are carried out not for later sale of the construction projects, but for their operation (e.g. space renting or manufacturing activities), the unit would not be classified here, but according to its operational activity, i.e. real estate, manufacturing, etc.

**410 - 4100 - 41000: Construction of buildings**

This class includes:

Complete residential or non-residential buildings, on one’s own account or on a fee or contract basis. Outsourcing parts or even the whole construction process is possible. If only specialized parts of the construction process are carried out, the activity is classified in division 41 (Construction of buildings).

\- Construction of all types of residential buildings:

\+ Single-family houses,

\+ Multi-family buildings, including high-rise buildings.

\- Construction of all types of non-residential buildings:

\+ Buildings for industrial production, e.g. factories, workshops, assembly plants, etc.

\+ Hospitals. Schools, office buildings,

\+ Hotels, stores, eat, restaurant chains, diners,

\+ Airport buildings,

\+ Indoor sports facilities,

\+ Parking garages, including underground ones,

\+ Warehouses,

\+ Religious buildings.

\- Assembly and erection of prefabricated constructions on the site;

\- Remodeling and renovating existing residential structures.

**Exclusion:**

\- Renovation of complete prefabricated constructions from self-manufactured parts not of concrete, under division 16 (Wood processing and manufacture of products of wood and bamboo (except furniture); manufacture of articles of straw and plaiting materials) and division 25 (Manufacture of fabricated metal products, except machinery and equipment);

\- Construction of industrial facilities, except buildings, under class 42900 (Construction of other civil engineering projects);

\- Architectural and engineering activities, under class 7110 (Architectural activities and related technical consultancy);

\- Project management activities related to construction, under class 7110 (Architectural activities and related technical consultancy).

**42: CIVIL ENGINEERING**

This division includes:

General construction for civil engineering works. It includes new work, repair, expansion and renovation, erection of pre-fabricated structures on the site and construction of temporary nature.

Also included is heavy construction works such as motorways, streets, bridges, tunnels, railways, airfields, harbors and other water projects, irrigation systems, industrial facilities, pipelines and electric lines, outdoor sports facilities, etc. This work can be carried out on one’s own account or on a fee or contract basis. Portions of the work and sometimes even the whole practical work can be subcontracted out.

**421 - 4210: Construction of railways and roads**

This class includes:

\- Construction of highways, motorways, roads, other vehicular and pedestrian ways;

\- - Surface work on streets, roads, highways, bridges or tunnels;

\- Asphalt paving of roads;

\- Road painting and other marking;

\- Installation of barriers, traffic signs and similar items;

\- Construction of bridges, including those for highways;

\- Construction of tunnels;

\- Construction of railways and subways;

\- Construction of airfield runways.

**Exclusion:**

\- Installation of street lighting and electrical signals, under class 43210 (Electrical installation);

\- Architectural and engineering activities, under group 661 (Financial service activities, except social insurance);

\- Project management activities, under group 661 (Financial service activities, except social insurance).

**42101: Construction of railways**

This class includes:

\- Construction of railways;

\- Railway painting;

\- Installation of railway barriers, traffic signs and similar items;

**42102: Construction of roads**

This class includes:

\- Construction of highways, motorways, roads, other vehicular and pedestrian ways;

\- Surface work on streets, roads, highways, bridges or tunnels:

\+ Asphalt paving of roads,

\+ Road painting and other marking,

\+ Installation of traffic signs and similar items,

\- Construction of bridges, including those for highways;

\- Construction of tunnels,

\- Construction of railways and subways,

\- Construction of airfield runways.

**Exclusion:** Construction and painting of railway, installation of railway barriers and traffic signs, under class 42101 (Construction of railway).

**422 - 4220 - 42200: Construction of utility projects**

This class includes:

Construction of transport and distribution lines and civil engineering works:

\+ Long-distance pipelines, power and telecommunication lines,

\+ Urban long-distance pipelines, power and telecommunication lines; ancillary urban works.

\- Construction of water mains and systems:

\+ Irrigation systems (canals),

\+ Reservoirs.

\- Construction of:

\+ Sewer systems, including repair works,

\+ Sewage treatment plants,

\+ Pumping stations,

\+ Power plants,

\- Water well drilling.

**Exclusion:** Project management activities related to civil engineering works, under class 7110 (Architectural activities and related technical consultancy).

**429 - 4290 - 42900: Construction of other civil engineering projects**

This class includes:

\- Construction of industrial facilities, except buildings, such as:

\+ Oil refineries,

\+ Chemical plants,

\- Construction of:

\+ Waterways, harbor and river works, tourist ports, locks, etc.

\+ Dams and dykes.

\- Construction of subways;

\- Other construction works, other than buildings, such as: Outdoor sports facilities.

This class also includes land subdivision with land improvement (e.g. adding of roads, utility infrastructure).

**Exclusion:** Project management activities related to civil engineering works, under class 7110 (Architectural activities and related technical consultancy).

**43: SPECIALIZED CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES**

This division includes specialized construction activities that serve a specific purpose or use. Such activities, compared with other works, require specialized skills or equipment, such as pile driving, foundation work, carcass work, concrete work, brick laying, stone setting, scaffolding, roof covering, etc. The erection of steel structures whose parts are not produced by the same unit is also included. Specialized construction activities are mostly carried out under subcontract, but especially in repair construction, it is done directly for the owner of the property. Also included are building finishing and completion activities.

The installation of all kind of utilities that the construction function must execute is included. These activities are usually performed at the site of the construction, although parts of the job may be carried out in a special workshop. Included are activities such as surveying, installation of heating and air-conditioning systems, antennas, alarm systems and other electrical work, sprinkler systems, elevators and escalators, etc. Also included are insulation work (water, heat, sound), sheet metal work, commercial refrigerating work, installation of illumination and signaling systems for roads, railways, airports, harbors, etc. Also included is the repair of the same type as the above-mentioned activities.

Building completion activities encompass activities that contribute to the completion or finishing of a construction such as glazing, plastering, coating, decorating, floor and wall tiling or covering with other materials like parquet, carpets, wallpaper, etc., floor sanding, finish carpentry, acoustical work, cleaning of the exterior, etc. Also included is the repair of the same type as the above-mentioned activities.

The renting of construction equipment with an operator is classified with the associated construction activity.

**431: Demolition and site preparation**

This group includes the activities of preparing a site for subsequent construction activities, including the removal of previously existing structures.

**4311 -  43110: Demolition**

This class includes the demolition or wrecking of buildings and other structures.

**4312 - 43120: Site preparation**

This class includes the preparation of construction sites. This class includes:

\- Clearing of building sites;

\- Earth moving: excavation, leveling and grading of construction sites, water drainage, rock removal, blasting, etc.

\- Preparation of mining sites: Overburden removal and other preparation of mineral properties and sites, except oil and gas sites;

\- Test drilling, boring and core sampling for geological, geophysical or similar purposes;

\- Drainage and supply of water at building sites;

\- Drainage and supply of water for agriculture and forestry;

\- Demining and similar activities (including detonation) at building sites.

**Exclusion:**

\- Drilling of wells for oil or gas production, under class 06100 (Extraction of crude petroleum), class 06200 (Extraction of natural gas);

\- Decontamination of soil, under class 39000 (Remediation activities and other waste management services);

\- Water well drilling, under class 42200 (Construction of utility projects);

\- Shaft sinking, under class 43900 (Other specialized construction activities);

\- Oil and gas field exploration, seismic, geophysical and geological surveying, under class 7110 (Architectural activities and related technical consultancy).

**432: Electrical, plumping and other construction installation activities**

This group includes installation activities that support the construction of a building, including installation of electrical systems, plumbing (water, gas and sewage systems), heating and air-conditioning systems, elevators, etc.

**4321 - 43210: Electrical installation**

This class includes:

Installation of electrical systems in all kinds of buildings and civil engineering structures;

This class includes:

\+ Electrical wiring and fittings,

\+ Communications wiring,

**G: WHOLESALE AND RETAIL TRADE; REPAIR OF MOTOR VEHICLES AND MOTORCYCLES**

This section includes wholesale and retail sale (i.e. sale without transformation) of any type of goods and the rendering of services incidental to the sale of these goods. Wholesaling and retailing are the final steps in the distribution of goods. Also included in this section is the repair of motor vehicles and motorcycles.

It includes manual operations associated with the sale of goods, for example, arranging, sorting, assembling of goods, mixing of goods (e.g. blending of wine or sand), packing, breaking bulk and repacking for distribution of goods in smaller lots, storage (whether or not frozen or chilled), cleaning and drying of agricultural products, cutting of wood fiberboards or metal sheets as secondary activities. Division 45 includes all activities related to the sale and repair of motor vehicles and motorcycles. Divisions 46 and 47 include all other sale activities (except motor vehicles and motorcycles). The distinction between division 46 (wholesale) and division 47 (retail trade), which both exclude motor vehicles and motorcycles, is based on the predominant type of customer.

Wholesale is the sale (sale without transformation) of new and used goods to retailers, to industrial, commercial, institutional or professional users, or to other wholesalers. It may involve acting as an agent or broker in buying goods for, or selling goods to, such persons or companies. The principal types of wholesale businesses are: Specialized wholesale merchants, industrial distributors, exporters, importers, and procurement associations, cooperatives, sales branches and sales offices (except retail stores) that are established by manufacturing or mining units for the purpose of marketing their products and that do not merely take orders to be filled by direct shipments from the plants or mines. Also included are merchandise brokers, agents, commission merchants and collectors of farm products. Wholesalers frequently physically assemble, sort and grade goods in large lots, break bulk, repack in smaller lots (e.g. pharmaceuticals) or store, refrigerate, deliver and install goods. They also engage in sales promotion for their customers and label design. Retailing is the resale (sale without transformation) of new and used goods mainly to the general public for personal or household consumption, by shops, supermarkets, department stores, stalls, mail-order houses, markets or door-to-door sales persons, sale cooperatives, auction houses, etc. Most retailers take title to the goods they sell, but some act as agents for a principal and sell either on consignment or on a commission basis.

**45: SALE AND REPAIR OF MOTOR VEHICLES AND MOTORCYCLES**

This division includes:

\- All activities (except manufacture and leasing) related to motor vehicles and motorcycles, including lorries and trucks, such as the wholesale and retail sale of new and second-hand vehicles, the repair and maintenance of vehicles and the wholesale and retail sale of parts and accessories thereof. Also included are activities of commission agents involved in wholesale or retail sale of such goods.

This division also includes the washing and polishing of motor vehicles.

**Exclusion:** Retail sale of automotive fuel and lubricating or cooling products or the leasing of motor vehicles or motorcycles.

**46: WHOLESALE TRADE (EXCEPT MOTOR VEHICLES AND MOTORCYCLES)**

This division includes:

Wholesale trade on one’s own account or through a commission agent, related to domestic and international wholesale trade (import and export).

Wholesale is the sale (without transformation) of new and used goods to retailers, to industrial, commercial, institutional or professional users, or resale to other wholesalers. It also involves acting as an agent or broker in buying goods for, or selling goods to, such persons or companies. The principal types of wholesale businesses are: Specialized wholesale merchants, industrial distributors, exporters, importers, and procurement associations, cooperatives, sales branches and sales offices (except retail stores) that are established by manufacturing or mining units for the purpose of marketing their products and that do not merely take orders to be filled by direct shipments from the plants or mines. Also included are merchandise brokers, agents, commission merchants and collectors of farm products.

Wholesalers frequently physically assemble, sort and grade goods in large lots, break bulk, repack in smaller lots (e.g. pharmaceuticals) or store, refrigerate, deliver and install goods. They also engage in sales promotion for their customers and label design.

**Exclusion:**

\- Wholesale of motorcycles and motor vehicles, under classes 45111 (Wholesale of small cars with 12 or fewer seats), 45411 (Wholesale of motorcycles) and 45119 (Wholesale of other motor vehicles);

\- Wholesale of parts and accessories for motorcycles and motor vehicles, under classes 45301 (Wholesale of motor vehicle parts and accessories) and 45431 (Wholesale of parts and accessories for motorcycles);

\- Renting and leasing of goods, under division 77 (Leasing of machinery and equipment without an operator); leasing of personal and household goods; leasing of non-financial intangible assets);

\- Packing of solid goods and bottling of liquid or gaseous goods, including blending and filtering at the buyer’s request, under class 82920 (Packaging activities).

**47: RETAIL TRADE (EXCEPT MOTOR VEHICLES AND MOTORCYCLES)**

This division includes:

Resale (sale without transformation) of new and used goods to the general public for personal or household consumption or social utilization, by specialized  and non-specialized shops, department stores, stalls, mail-order houses, consumer cooperatives, mobile vendors or markets.

Retail trade is classified first by type of sale outlet. Retail trade thereof is classified into: retail trade in stores under groups from 471 (Retail sale in non-specialized stores) to 477 (Retail sale of other goods in specialized stores); non-store retail trade under groups 478 (Retail sale visa stalls or markets) and 479 (Retail trade not in stores, stalls or markets).

Retail trade in stores, including retail sale of used goods, is classified under class 4774 (Retail sale of second-hand goods in specialized stores). There exists a further distinction between specialized retail sale under groups from 472 (Retail sale of food, beverages, and tobacco in specialized stores) to 477 (Retail sale of other goods in specialized stores) and non-specialized retail sale under group 471 (Retail sale in non-specialized stores). The above groups are further subdivided into 4th and 5th levels by the type of products sold.

Sale not via stores is subdivided according to the forms of trade, such as retail sale via stalls, kiosks and markets, under group 478 (Retail sale via stalls or markets) and other non-store retail sale, e.g. mail order, Internet shopping, door-to-door, by vending machines, etc. under class 479 (Retail trade not in stores, stalls or markets). The goods sold in the retail trade are usually referred to as consumer goods. Goods not usually entering the retail trade, such as ores, industrial machinery and equipment, are excluded. This division also includes units engaged primarily in selling to organizations some consumer products such as personal computers, stationery, paint or timber, although these sales may not be for personal or household use. Some processing of goods incidental to sale activities may be included, e.g. sorting, storing, packing and installation of household goods.

This division also includes the retail sale by commission agents and activities of retail auctioning houses.

**Exclusion:**

\- Sale of farm products by farmers, under division 01 (Agriculture and related services)

\- Manufacture of sale of goods, generally classified as manufacturing, under divisions 10 to 32;

\- Sale of motor vehicles, motorcycles and their parts, under division 45 (Sale and repair of motor vehicles and motorcycles);

\- Trade in ores, crude oil, industrial chemicals, iron, steel, industrial machinery, equipment and related supplies, under division 46 (Wholesale trade, except motor vehicles and motorcycles);

\- Sale of food and drinks for consumption on the premises and sale of takeaway food, under division 56 (Food and beverage services);

\- Leasing of personal and household goods, under group 772 (Leasing of personal and household goods).

**479: Other retail sale (except retail sale via stalls or markets)**

This group includes retail sale activities by mail order, over the Internet, through door-to-door sales, vending machines, etc.

**4791 - 47910: Retail sale via mail order or via Internet**

This class includes retail sale activities in which the buyer makes his choice on the basis of advertisements, catalogues, information provided on a website, samples or any other means of advertising. The buyer then places his order by mail, phone or over the Internet (usually through special means provided by a website). The products purchased can be either directly downloaded from the Internet or physically delivered to the customer.

This class includes:

\- Retail sale of goods by mail order;

\- Retail sale of products over the Internet.

This class also includes:

\- Direct sale via television, radio and telephone;

\- Internet-based retail auctions.

**4799 - 47990: Other retail sale not elsewhere classified**

This class includes:

\- Retail sale of goods in any way that is not included in previous classes: by direct sales or door-to-door salespersons or through vending machines, etc.;

\- Direct selling of fuel (heating oil, fuel wood), delivered directly to the consumers' premises;

\- Activities of non-store auctions (retail);

\- Retail sale by (non-store) commission agents.

**Exclusion:** Delivery of products by stores, under groups from 471 (Retail sale in non-specialized stores) to 477 (Retail sale of other goods in specialized stores).

**H: TRANSPORTATION AND STORAGE**

This section includes:

Provision of passenger or freight transport, whether scheduled or on demand, by rail, pipeline, road, water or air and associated activities such as parking facilities, harbors, airfields, railway stations, cargo handling and storage, etc.

This section also includes:

Leasing of transport equipment with a driver or operator. Postal and courier activities.

**Exclusion:**

\- Major repair or replacement of transport equipment, except motor vehicles and motorcycles, under class 33150 (Repair and maintenance of transport equipment, except motor vehicles);

\- Construction, maintenance and repair of road, railroads, harbors, airfields, under classes 42101 (Construction of roads) and 42900 (Construction of other civil engineering projects);

\- Maintenance and repair of motorcycles and motor vehicles, under classes 4520 (Maintenance and repair of motor vehicles) and 4542 (Maintenance and repair of motorcycles);

\- Leasing of transport equipment without a driver or operator, under class 7710 (Leasing of motor vehicles).

**49: LAND TRANSPORT AND TRANSPORT VIA PIPELINES**

This division includes the activities of transport of passengers and freight via road and railway, and transport of freight via pipelines.

**491: Transport via railways**

This group includes the rail transportation of passengers and/or freight by railroad rolling stock on mainline networks spreading over a region, a geographic area or a short-line local railroad.

**Exclusion:**

\- Related activities such as switching and shunting, under class 52211 (Service activities incidental to rail transportation);

\- Maintenance of railway systems, under class 52211 (Service activities incidental to rail transportation).

**4911 - 49110: Passenger rail transport**

This class includes:

\- Passenger transport by inter-provincial railways;

\- Operation of sleeping cars and dining cars as an integrated operation of railway companies.

**Exclusion:**

\- Passenger transport by urban and suburban railway systems, under class 49311 (Passenger transport by underground railroad);

\- Rail passenger terminal activities, under class 52211 (Service activities incidental to rail transportation);

\- Operation of sleeping and dining cars by a separate unit, under classes 55909 (Other accommodation not elsewhere classified) and 56290 (Other food services).

**4912 - 49120: Freight rail transport**

This class includes the activities of freight transport on inter-provincial, urban and suburban railroads.

**Exclusion:**

\- Storage and warehousing, under group 521 (Warehousing and storage);

\- Rail freight terminal activities, under class 52211 (Service activities incidental to rail transportation);

\- Cargo handling, under class 52241 (Rail freight handling).

**492 - 4920 - 49200: Transport by bus**

This class includes:

\- Passenger transport by urban, suburban or inter-provincial buses;

\- Transport, on a contract basis, of pupils to schools or workers to workplaces.

**493: Other land transport**

This group includes land-based passenger and freight transport activities (except Transport by bus and rail transport).

**4931: Urban and suburban passenger land transport (except Transport by bus)**

This class includes the activities of land transport of passengers in urban or suburban areas, by different modes of land transport (except buses), such as: underground and elevated railways, streetcars, tramway, etc. The nature of such transport is that it is carried out on scheduled at fixed stops.

This class also includes:

\- Town-to-airport or town-to-station lines;

\- Operation of funicular railways, aerial cableways, etc. as part of an urban or suburban transit system.

**Exclusion:**

\- Passenger transport by inter-provincial railways, under class 49110 (Rail passenger transport);

\- Transport by bus, under class 49200 (Transport by bus);

**49311: Passenger transport by underground railway**

This class includes the activities of urban and suburban passenger transport by underground electric railways.

**49312: Passenger transport by taxicabs**

This class includes the activities of passenger transport by taxicabs, including airport transfer taxicabs.

**49313: Passenger transport by three-wheeler lambros, ricksaws and motorcycles**

This class includes:

\- Passenger transport by three-wheeler lambros;

\- Passenger transport by ricksaws;

\- Passenger transport by motorcycles.

**Exclusion:** Leasing of auto ricksaws and motorcycles without a driver, under class 77309 (Leasing of other machinery, equipment and tangible goods not elsewhere classified).

**49319: Passenger transport by bicycles, cyclos and non-motorized vehicles**

This class includes:

\- Passenger transport by bicycles;

\- Passenger transport by cyclos;

\- Passenger transport by non-motorized vehicles such as horse-drawn carts, bullock carts, etc.

**Exclusion:** Leasing of bicycles, cyclos and non-motorized vehicles without a driver, under class 77309 (Leasing of other machinery, equipment and tangible goods not elsewhere classified).

**4932: Other passenger land transport**

This class includes:

\- Passenger transport by intra-provincial and inter-provincial vehicles;

\- Chartering of vehicles with driver for passenger transport, tourist excursions or other purposes;

\- Operation of cable cars and funiculars.

**Exclusion:**

\- Leasing of vehicles without a driver, under class 77309 (Leasing of other machinery, equipment and tangible goods not elsewhere classified).

\- Ambulance transport, under class 86990 (Other health activities not elsewhere classified).

**49321: Passenger transport by intra-provincial and inter-provincial vehicles**

This class includes:

\- Passenger transport by intra-provincial vehicles travelling between urban and suburban districts of a city or of a province;

\- Passenger transport by inter-provincial vehicles;

\- Chartering of vehicles with driver for passenger transport, tourist excursions or other purposes;

**Exclusion:** Leasing of passenger vehicles without a driver, under class 77309 (Leasing of other machinery, equipment and tangible goods not elsewhere classified).

**49329: Other passenger land transport not elsewhere classified**

This class includes the operation of funicular railways, aerial cableways, etc. as part of an urban or suburban transit system.

**4933: Freight transport by road**

This class includes:

\- Transportation of ordinary goods: wood, livestock, forest products, aquatic products, other ordinary goods;

\- Transportation of goods by special-purpose vehicles: tank trucks, chemical trucks, refrigerated trucks;

\- Heavy haulage and transportation of containers;

\- Transportation of waste and waste materials, without collection or disposal.

This class also includes:

\- Furniture relocation;

\- Leasing of trucks with driver;

\- Freight transport by man-drawn or animal-drawn vehicles.

**Exclusion:**

\- Log hauling within a forest, as part of logging operations, under class 02400 (Support services to forestry);

\- Distribution of water by trucks, under class 36000 (Water collection, treatment and supply);

\- Operation of terminal facilities for handling freight, under class 52219 (Service activities incidental to land transportation);

\- Crating and packing services for transport, under class 52299 (Other transportation support activities not elsewhere classified);

\- Postal services and courier activities, under classes 53100 (Postal activities and 53200 (Courier activities);

\- Waste transport as integrated part of waste collection activities, under classes 38110 (Collection of non-hazardous waste), 38121 (Collection of medical waste) and 38129 (Collection of other hazardous waste).

**49331: Freight transport by special-purpose automobiles**

This class includes:

\- Haulage in tanker trucks;

\- Haulage in chemical trucks;;

\- Refrigerated food transport;

\- Leasing of freight vehicles with driver.

**Exclusion:**

\- Distribution of water by trucks, under class 36000 (Water collection, treatment and supply);

\- Waste transport as integrated part of waste collection activities, under classes 38110 (Collection of non-hazardous waste), 38121 (Collection of medical waste) and 38129 (Collection of other hazardous waste).

\- Leasing of special-purposed vehicles without a driver, under class 77309 (Leasing of other machinery, equipment and tangible goods not elsewhere classified).

**49332: Freight transport by other automobiles (except special-purpose vehicles)**

This class includes:

\- Transportation of ordinary goods: wood, livestock, forest products, aquatic products, other normal goods;

\- Heavy haulage and transportation of containers;

\- Transportation of waste and waste materials, without collection or disposal.

This class also includes:

\- Relocation of household and office furniture and equipment, etc.;

\- Leasing of freight vehicles (except special-purpose vehicles) with driver.

**Exclusion:**

\- Log hauling within a forest, as part of logging operations, under class 02400 (Support services to forestry);

\- Operation of terminal facilities for handling freight, under class 52219 (Service activities incidental to land transportation);

\- Crating and packing services for transport, under class 52299 (Other transportation support activities not elsewhere classified);

\- Postal services and courier activities, under classes 53100 (Postal activities and 53200 (Courier activities);

\- Leasing of freight vehicles without a driver, under class 77109 (Leasing of other motor vehicles).

**49333: Freight transport by three-wheeler lambros, ricksaws and modified tractors**

This class includes:

\- Transportation of ordinary goods by three-wheeler lambros, ricksaws and modified tractors;

\- Leasing of three-wheeler lambros, ricksaws and modified tractors for goods transport.

**49334: Freight transport by non-motorized vehicles**

This class includes the transportation of goods by improved carts, bullock carts, horse-drawn or animal-drawn carts.

**49339: Other road freight transport**

This class includes:

Road freight transport by other means not elsewhere classified.

**494 - 4940 - 49400: Transport via pipeline**

This class includes the transportation of gases, liquefied gases, water, liquids, slurry and other commodities via pipelines.

This class also includes the operation of pump stations.

**Exclusion:**

\- Distribution of natural or manufactured gas, water or steam, under classes 35200 (Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains), 3530 (Manufacture and supply of steam, hot water, air conditioning and ice) and 36000 (Water collection, treatment and supply);

\- Transportation of water, liquids, etc. by tanker trucks, under class 49331 (Freight transport by special-purpose vehicles).

**50: WATER TRANSPORT**

This division includes the transportation of passengers or freight over water, whether scheduled or not. Operation of towing or pushing boats, cruise ships or sightseeing boats, ferries, water taxis, etc. Although the geographical location is an indicator for the separation between sea and inland waterway transport, the deciding factor is the type of vessel used. All transport on sea-going vessels is classified in group 501 (Coastal and seawater transport), while transport using other vessels is classified in group 502 (Inland water transport).

**Exclusion:** Restaurant and bar activities on board ships, if carried out by separate units, under classes 56101 (Restaurant and food serving places) and 56301 (Taverns and bars).

**501: Coastal and seawater transport**

This class includes the transportation of passengers or freight on vessels designed for operating on sea or coastal waters.

Also included is the transportation of passengers or freight on great lakes, etc. when similar types of sea vessels are used.

**5011: Coastal and sea passenger water transport**

This class includes:

\- Transportation of passengers overseas and coastal waters, whether scheduled or not;

\- Operation of cruise ships or sightseeing boats;

\- Operation of ferries and water taxis.

This class also includes the activities of chartering of vessels with crew for coastal and seawater transport (e.g. fishing cruises).

**Exclusion:**

\- Restaurant and bar activities on board ships, if carried out by separate units, under classes 56101 (Restaurant and food serving places) and 56301 (Taverns and bars).

\- Operation of "floating casinos”, under class 92002 (Betting and gambling activities), if operated by separate units.

**50111: Coastal passenger water transport**

This class includes:

\- Transportation of passengers over coastal waters, whether scheduled or not;

\- Operation of excursion or sightseeing boats;

\- Operation of ferries and water taxis.

This class also includes the activities of chartering of vessels with crew for coastal water transport (e.g. fishing cruises).

**Exclusion:**

\- Restaurant and bar activities on board ships, if carried out by separate units, under classes 56101 (Restaurant and food serving places) and 56301 (Taverns and bars).

\- Operation of "floating casinos”, under class 92002 (Betting and gambling activities), if operated by separate units.

**50112: Sea passenger water transport**

This class includes:

\- Transportation of passengers overseas waters, whether scheduled or not;

\- Operation of cruise ships or sightseeing boats.

This class also includes the activities of chartering of vessels with crew for seawater transport (e.g. fishing cruises).

**Exclusion:** Restaurant and bar activities on board ships, if carried out by separate units, under classes 56101 (Restaurant and food serving places) and 56301 (Taverns and bars).

**5012: Coastal and sea freight water transport**

This class includes:

\- Transportation of freight overseas and coastal waters, whether scheduled or not;

\- Transport by towing or pushing of barges, oil rigs, etc.

**Exclusion:**

\- Storage of freight, under group 521 (Warehousing and storage);

\- Harbor operation and other auxiliary activities such as docking, piloting, lighterage, vessel salvage, under class 52221 (Service activities incidental to coastal and seawater transport);

\- Cargo handling, under class 52243 (Seaport cargo handling).

**50121: Coastal freight water transport**

This class includes:

\- Coastal freight water transport, whether scheduled or not;

\- Transport by towing or pushing of barges, oil rigs, etc.

**Exclusion:**

\- Storage of freight, under group 521 (Warehousing and storage);

\- Harbor operation and other auxiliary activities such as docking, piloting, lighterage, vessel salvage, under class 52221 (Service activities incidental to coastal and seawater transport);

\- Cargo handling, under class 52243 (Seaport cargo handling).

**50122: Sea freight water transport**

This class includes:

\- Sea freight water transport, whether scheduled or not;

\- Transport by towing or pushing of barges, oil rigs, etc.

**Exclusion:**

\- Storage of freight, under group 521 (Warehousing and storage);

\- Harbor operation and other auxiliary activities such as docking, piloting, lighterage, vessel salvage, under class 52221 (Service activities incidental to coastal and seawater transport);

\- Cargo handling, under class 52243 (Seaport cargo handling).

**502: Inland water transport**

This class includes: Transport of passengers or freight on rivers, lakes and canals, involving vessels that are not suitable for sea transport or other motorized vessels (ferries, motorized boats and skiffs) and non-motorized vessels (non-motorized boats and skiffs).

**5021: Inland passenger water transport**

This class includes the transportation of passengers via rivers, lakes and canals by motorized and non-motorized vessels.

This class also includes the activities of chartering of ships with crew or leasing of skiffs with operator for transporting passengers via rivers, lakes and canals.
